About LVMH Moët Hennessy - Louis Vuitton, Société Européenne

LVMH Moët Hennessy - Louis Vuitton, Société Européenne operates as a luxury goods company worldwide. The company offers wines, and spirits under the domaine des Lambrays, Château d'Yquem, Dom Pérignon, Ruinart, Moët & Chandon, Hennessy, Veuve Clicquot, Château Galoupet, Ardbeg, Château Cheval Blanc, Glenmorangie, Krug, Mercier, Chandon, Joseph Phelps, Newton Vineyard, Cloudy Bay, Belvedere, Colgin Cellars,Terrazas de los Andes, Bodega Numanthia, Cheval des Andes, Woodinville, Ao Yun, Clos19, Volcan de mi Tierra, and Eminente brands; and fashion and leather products under the Loewe, Moynat, Louis Vuitton, Berluti, RIMOWA, Patou, Loro Piana, FENDI, Celine, Christian Dior, Emilio Pucci, Givenchy, Kenzo, and Marc Jacobs brands.

2.title: LVMH Watch Week, sixth edition in New York and Paris for the nine Maisons of iconic watchmaking brands
2.snippet: After hosting LVMH Watch Week in Dubai, Singapore and then Miami in 2024, LVMH has chosen New York and Paris to kick off 2025, bringing together its Maisons...
2.content:
After hosting LVMH Watch Week in Dubai, Singapore and then Miami in 2024, LVMH has chosen New York and Paris to kick off 2025, bringing together its Maisons to connect two continents that are central to the LVMH Group's DNA.

LVMH will host the sixth edition of the LVMH Watch Week il January 21st and 22nd in New York and the January 30th and 31st in Paris. Nine LVMH watchmaking Maisons will present their latest creations during the events.

Building on the success of previous editions, LVMH Watch Week 2025 takes the event, which has become a must-attend event on the watch industry calendar, to a new level this year. To the prestigious Maisons that have regularly taken part in this event – Bvlgari, Hublot, TAG Heuer, Zenith, Daniel Roth and Gérald Genta – three more iconic brands will be added in 2025, Louis Vuitton, Tiffany & Co. and L'Epée 1839.

During this sixth edition of LVMH Watch Week, each Maison will offer attendees an exclusive look at its latest creations, highlighting the enormous creative dynamic within the Group’s Watch division. Highlights include Bvlgari’s Serpenti Seduttori collection, Daniel Roth’s Extra Plat Souscription, Gérald Genta’s Gentissima Oursin Fire Opal, Hublot’s Big Bang Meca-10 collection, Louis Vuitton’s Tambour Taiko Spin Time collection, TAG Heuer’s Formula 1 chronograph, L’Epée 35’s T1839 collection, Tiffany & Co. Jean Schlumberger collection, and Zenith’s Defy. Skyline Skeleton Chronograph.

LVMH in the United States, a strategic market

The United States plays a key role in the luxury sector and is a strategic market for LVMH and its Maisons. The LVMH Group has over 43.000 employees and 1.128 stores in the United States. The country is a key growth driver for the Group and its Maisons, representing 25% of the Group’s sales in 2023. Louis Vuitton, Dior and Sephora in particular have performed very well in 2024 in the United States, and the launch of SirDavis American whiskey is emblematic of LVMH’s dynamic momentum and continued innovation in this market.

New York and Paris to celebrate the Maison, where?

The New York event takes place in the heart of Manhattan at Tiffany’s iconic flagship, The Landmark, on 5th Avenue, as well as nearby Louis Vuitton and Bvlgari stores. In Paris, the LVMH Group’s Cheval Blanc Paris hotel will provide an equally majestic space to welcome the European press, along with stores from several Maisons.

5.title: Meet the Four African Designers Named Semi-Finalists for the 2025 LVMH Prize
5.snippet: In exciting news for African fashion, David Boye–Doe, Tolu Coker, Torishéju Dumi, and Yasmin Mansour have been named among the 20 semi-finalists for the...
5.content:
In exciting news for African fashion, David Boye–Doe, Tolu Coker, Torishéju Dumi, and Yasmin Mansour have been named among the 20 semi-finalists for the 12th edition of the prestigious LVMH Prize for Young Designers, highlighting the growing recognition of African talent in global fashion.

This isn’t the first time African designers have caught the eye of the LVMH Prize. In 2019, South Africa’s Thebe Magugu became the first African designer to take home the grand prize. Priya Ahluwalia, a British Indian Nigerian designer, was a finalist in 2020, and Lukhanyo Mdingi from Cape Town won the Special Prize in 2021.

The LVMH Prize is a major platform for young designers, offering €400,000 to the winner along with a year of mentorship in key areas like sustainable practices, marketing, and brand management. There are also two other awards—the Karl Lagerfeld Prize and the Savoir-Faire Prize, each with €200,000 and a year of mentorship.

The 20 semi-finalists will showcase their collections during Paris Fashion Week on March 5th and 6th. With the competition becoming more competitive, we’re particularly thrilled about these four African designers who have made it this far.

Meet them below:

David Kusi Boye-Doe “Boyedoe” (Ghana)

Founded in 2020 by David Boye-Doe, Boyedoe is the first Ghanaian brand to participate in the LVMH Prize. David Boye-Doe combines Afrofuturism with traditional West African tailoring, creating bold, genderless designs with structured silhouettes. The brand is committed to sustainability, focusing on deconstruction and reconstruction in its designs. Drawing inspiration from the Sankofa bird, a symbol in Ghanaian culture, Boyedoe uses fashion to explore and reimagine African heritage in a socially and environmentally responsible way.

Since its international debut as a finalist for ARISE 30 Under 30 New Stars in Lagos, Boyedoe has launched four collections, including his most recent at the Lagos Fashion Weekend in October last year.

Tolu Coker (Nigeria)

Tolu Coker, a British-Nigerian designer, is reshaping womenswear by placing identity and heritage at the heart of her designs. Her collections explore themes of migration, race, and cultural storytelling, often incorporating hand-dyed fabrics and up-cycled materials. As a passionate advocate for sustainable fashion, she founded her brand in 2021 with the aim of redefining luxury through sustainability, inclusivity, and cultural preservation.

Drawing on her own heritage and a family legacy of social activism, Tolu Coker’s work blends quality tailoring, craftsmanship, and cultural narratives. She combines traditional techniques like batik, loom weaving, and hand-embroidery with modern technologies, creating collections that connect the past with the future. Her bold approach has caught the attention of stars like Tems and Doechii, who have worn her creations. Beyond fashion, her brand also extends into exhibitions, films, and global projects, challenging industry standards and using luxury as a platform for equity, heritage, and social impact

Torisheju Dumi (Nigeria)

Torisheju Dumi, the designer behind the UK-based brand Torisheju, launched her label with the goal of pushing the limits of contemporary fashion.

Her collections combine menswear and womenswear, featuring sculptural, artistic designs, architectural structures, fluid draping, and avant-garde aesthetic. Torisheju gained attention after dressing Zendaya for the “Dune: Part Two” photocall, which brought her work into the spotlight.

Growing up, Torisheju was exposed to fashion through her mother’s passion for 19th-century design and art. Her Nigerian-Brazilian, Catholic upbringing also influences her work, with themes of religion, tradition, and spirituality playing a central role. Torisheju graduated with an MA in Fashion from Central Saint Martins and is an alumna of the Sarabande Foundation. She has also gained invaluable experience at Céline with Phoebe Philo, as well as at Ann Demeulemeester, Giles Deacon, and Sibling London.

Yasmin Mansour (Egypt)

Yasmin Mansour founded her eponymous brand in 2014 with a focus on creating a dialogue between sculptural elegance and artistic expression. Based in Qatar, her label is known for architectural silhouettes, intricate pleating, and a reverence for traditional craftsmanship.

Her designs combine texture and structure to present a refined approach to luxury, where fashion meets contemporary art. Every creation embodies a thoughtful balance of innovation and artistry, making Yasmin Mansour’s work a celebration of both craft and creativity.

7.title: LVMH Beauty and The Shilla Duty Free unveil exclusive Miss Dior pop-up at Changi Airport
7.snippet: The Couture Twirl pop-up, inspired by Miss Dior's bow detail, offers an array of interactive beauty experiences. SINGAPORE. Dior (LVMH Beauty) has partnered...
7.content:
SINGAPORE. Parfums Christian Dior has partnered with The Shilla Duty Free and Changi Airport Group to launch the exclusive Miss Dior ‘The Couture Twirl’ animation at Singapore Changi Airport.

Running from 16 January to 11 March in Terminal 3, the activation celebrates Miss Dior’s rich brand universe while offering a multi-sensory beauty experience to travellers. It is described as “an illuminating celebration” of Miss Dior’s fragrance heritage.

The pop-up was launched to engage travellers throughout the peak Lunar New Year and Valentine’s Day travel and gifting season.

The immersive showcase is topped with a Miss Dior bow, replicating the fragrance bottle’s decoration, alongside the brand’s signature logo from 1967. Inspired by Dior’s traditional craftsmanship, the pop-up also features intricate embroidery and couture finishes.

Exclusive and experiental elements

Travellers are invited to discover the Miss Dior bottle at the pop-up’s entrance. Once inside, they can engage with various touchpoints including a Photo Moment station, a Miss Dior Light Up Experience and a beauty discovery zone.

The centrepiece is a grand ribbon recreation of the Miss Dior bottle, which is activated when visitors place a Miss Dior fragrance bottle on its pedestal. The installation creates a dynamic photo and video opportunity for travellers.

Visitors can explore the world of Miss Dior through a couture-inspired fabric consultation, where they receive personalised fragrance recommendations based on textile textures such as silk, velvet, cashmere, lace and tulle.

A dedicated Beauty Fitting area offers skincare consultations powered by Dior’s skincare analyser and makeup sessions incorporating the new Dior Addict Lip Glow range.

To further personalise the experience, a sketching service and embroidery personalisation are available with selected purchases.

Notably, the pop-up marks the debut of the Miss Dior Café in Asia Pacific travel retail, offering customers exclusive beverages and desserts inspired by The Couture Twirl concept. The café, open to those who make a purchase, adds an experiential layer to the beauty journey.

Exclusive launches and limited editions

Travellers can shop a variety of exclusive lines and collectibles at the activation. The Miss Dior Mini Miss is a travel-friendly, refillable fragrance collection housed in elegant jacquard cases.

Designed to mimic a lipstick case, the line is available in pearl grey and pink for Miss Dior Eau de Parfum, soft pink for Miss Dior Blooming Bouquet and black and pink for Miss Dior Parfum. In addition, ‘Miss Dior’ is stitched in white on a pink background, adding a couture signature to the cases.

The Miss Dior Parfum, an intense chypre composition infused with bespoke fruity jasmine and notes of wild strawberry, is also available.

In addition, Dior has partnered with French artist Eva Jospin to create a colourful hand-embroidered motif for a special Miss Dior trunk. The motif is entirely hand-embroidered by Ateliers Chanakya in India, and houses a glass bottle of Miss Dior adorned with a houndstooth pattern and dagger bow.

Only 116 mini trunks, designed by Jospin, have been released globally with two available for purchase at Changi Airport.

The pop-up showcases the Dior Addict Lip Glow, reimagined with an enhanced formula and colour palette. The range has been expanded to include warm undertones and is made with 97% natural-origin ingredients.

Infused with cherry oil, Dior Addict Lip Glow offers 24-hour hydration that protects lips with a natural barrier. Its formula adjusts to the wearer’s pH, creating a tailored glow for each skin type.

The partners celebrated the pop-up on 6 February with an official ribbon-cutting ceremony. The event welcomed senior executives representing Dior, Changi Airport Group and The Shilla Duty Free.

The Shilla Duty Free Vice President and Head of International Business Jeff Lee commented: “Travellers today are seeking new and exclusive retail concepts, so it is a privilege to unveil the Miss Dior pop-up, The Couture Twirl in collaboration with Dior and Changi Airport Group.

“Miss Dior is an eternal icon of youth, independence and female empowerment. We hope that the pop-up inspires travellers to discover, experience and gift this inspiring spirit as they travel through Singapore at the start of 2025.”

“The Miss Dior pop-up, The Couture Twirl, in Singapore embodies our vision to redefine beauty discovery in travel retail Asia Pacific,” added Dior APAC and LVMH Beauty APAC Travel Retail Managing Director Catherine Sauvage. “Travellers today seek uniquely curated experiences that blend iconic heritage with modern relevance, unlocking fresh opportunities for storytelling and engagement.

“The Couture Twirl brings to life Miss Dior’s duality of timeless elegance and contemporary edge, captivating the next generation of beauty enthusiasts. We thank our partners at The Shilla Duty Free and Changi Airport Group for their continued collaboration in elevating Dior Maison’s legacy and vision for travellers in Singapore.” ✈

8.title: Egyptian Brand Yasmin Mansour Shortlisted for Global 2025 LVMH Prize
8.snippet: For over a decade, the LVMH Prize for Young Fashion Designers has served as a springboard for emerging talent, amplifying the voices of those set to define...
8.content:
Egyptian Brand Yasmin Mansour Shortlisted for Global 2025 LVMH Prize

For over a decade, the LVMH Prize for Young Fashion Designers has served as a springboard for emerging talent, amplifying the voices of those set to define the industry’s future. This year, among the 2,300 applicants who entered the race for one of fashion’s most prestigious mentorships and funding opportunities, Yasmin Mansour is among the select few moving one step closer to the prize. The Egyptian designer, whose eponymous label operates out of Qatar, has secured a coveted spot among the 20 semi-finalists.







Mansour’s design ethos lies in her sculptural approach to womenswear—meticulously structured, yet inherently fluid. Since establishing her brand in 2014, she has mastered the interplay of architecture and movement, and the balance of traditional craftsmanship with modern elements like pleats, layers, and three-dimensional forms. Her approach to fashion is equal parts engineering and emotion, crafting silhouettes that call for attention without sacrificing grace.



On March 5th and 6th of this year, she will present her collection in Paris, competing for the chance to win a EUR 400,000 grant and a year-long mentorship under the guidance of LVMH’s industry leaders.

2.title: Sinéad O’Dwyer and Tolu Coker among semi-finalists for LVMH Prize
2.snippet: A number of UK and Ireland designers have made it to the semi-final of the prestigious LVMH Prize following a selection process that brought together over.
2.content:
A number of UK and Ireland designers have made it to the semi-final of the prestigious LVMH Prize following a selection process that brought together over 2,300 applicants from across the world. Among those on the list are that of Irish womenswear designer Sinéad O’Dwyer, as well as UK-based Tolu Coker, Torisheju and Steve O Smith.

Other names revealed as semi-finalists include France’s Alainpaul; US designers All-In, Josh Tafoya and Meruert Tolegen; Japan’s Pillings and Soshiotsuki; Francesco Murano, an Italian womenswear designer; Ghana-based Boyedoe; KML, from Saudi Arabia; Denmark’s Mfpen and Nicklas Skovgaard; Dutch brand Zomer; China’s Penultimate; Renaissance Renaissance, from Lebanon; Egyptian label Yasmin Mansour; and South Korean brand Young n Sang.

The 20 semi-finalists are a part of what is the 12th edition of the LVMH Prize, through which they will present their collections in a showroom taking place in Paris on March 5 and 6.

From March 5 to 9, a voting process will then be open to the general public, who will be able to vote for their eight favourite candidates, akin to a committee of experts made up of 80 international fashion specialists. This will determine the eight finalists.

As was the case for previous editions, three awards will be up for grabs; the LVMH Prize for Young Designers, offering a 400,000 euro endowment, the Karl Largerfeld Prize, with a 200,000 euro endowment, and the newer Savoir-Faire Prize, providing a 200,000 euro endowment. Each award also comes with a dedicated one-year mentorship programme.

An additional prize will be awarded to three young fashion school graduates, each of which will receive 10,000 euros and the chance to join the design team of one of LVMH’s portfolio brands for one year.

3.title: Live News: German investor outlook jumps by most in two years; Midday market update
3.snippet: Bite-sized servings of the latest in business, tech and current affairs.
3.content:
Bite-sized servings of the latest in business, tech and current affairs

Welcome to the Business Post’s Live News section. We’re here all day to keep you up to date on developments in business, tech and current affairs.

17.00 - Digicel plans redundancies

Digicel, the telecoms company founded by Denis O’Brien in Jamaica, is set to cut jobs as part of a drive aimed at staying “relevant and competitive”.

Digicel, which has 5,000 employees, said that 1.5 per cent of roles would be impacted.

The Irish Times has more.

16.45 - Aircoach scales back Dublin Airport services amid falling demand

Aircoach has announced service reductions on its Dublin and Wicklow routes to and from Dublin Airport, citing declining passenger demand.

From 2 March, the 700 route will run solely between Dublin Airport and Leopardstown, with services to Galloping Green, Foxrock, Cabinteely, Cornelscourt, and Cherrywood discontinued.

The 701 route will be rebranded as the 700X, operating as a shuttle between Dublin Airport and the city centre. Stops in Ballsbridge and at St Vincent’s Hospital will now be covered by Route 702.

RTÉ has the full breakdown.

16.30 - Iseq closes in the green

The Iseq All Share Index closed in the green today, up 0.40 per cent on previous close.

While shares in Kerry Group rose to a 12-month high of €100.40 on Tuesday afternoon as analysts reacted positively to the company’s performance, they fell to €96.65 at close of day. Kerry Group finished on -1.78 per cent since previous close.

16.10 - Clúid brings 46 Google-owned Boland’s Mills apartments to rental market for frontline workers

Clúid Housing has announced it’s offering 46 discounted rent apartments at Boland’s Mills for frontline workers, such as gardaí and nurses.

It comes after the Business Post revealed earlier this month Clúid had been chosen by tech giant Google as the approved housing body to let the apartments.

Vish Gain reports.

15.55 - Michael O’Flynn says no to developer tax breaks

Michael O’Flynn has dismissed the “noise” around potential tax breaks for housing developers.

Speaking at a Property Institute Ireland (PII) event on Tuesday, the Cork-based developer called for increased government oversight on property valuations in order to take the “mystery” out of housing supply.

Eoin O’Hare has the story.

15.35 - UK least attractive nation to invest in - survey

Picture: Getty

Britain has become the least attractive market to invest in, with the country’s stagnant economy being blamed.

A survey of global fund managers found sentiment towards the UK is now at an 11-month low.

The survey also showed that the country is less popular to invest in than cash, banks, energy and utilities

The Telegraph has more.

15.15 - ‘All options should be on the table’ including developer tax breaks - housing minister

“Everything has to be on the table” including tax incentives for developers, James Browne said on Tuesday, despite Paschal Donohoe, the finance minister, categorically rejecting the idea.

The new housing minister said that no decisions had been made but that “everything needs to be available to be discussed” as the government comes under increasing pressure to revamp its housing policy.

Cónal Thomas has more.

14.55 - Napier AI to create 100 jobs with new €12 million Belfast office

Napier AI, a London-based firm that creates software to tackle money laundering and financial crime, has committed to a £10 million new office in Belfast.

The firm, which saw California-based Marlin Equity Partners take a majority interest in it earlier this month, is expected to grow to over 100 staff in the next two years.

It was granted £689,000 in incentives by State body Invest NI in order to attract the roles.

The Irish News has more.

14.40 - US markets open: Dow Jones slips just after open

Photo by Spencer Platt

Markets in the US opened after a break for President’s Day on Monday, with the Dow Jones sliding by 0.1 per cent just after a high open.

The Federal Reserve’s rate cut policy is in focus, as is ongoing developments over Trump’s campaign of tariffs.

The Nasdaq rose over 0.2 per cent as of 14.39 IST, while the S&P 500 saw a 0.1 per cent climb.

14.30 - Medtronic pre-market shares slip as revenue slightly misses mark

Medtronic, the American-Irish medical device company, posted revenues of $8.29 billion in its third quarter, slightly below estimates, which has seen its share price fall in pre-market trading.

Analysts’ expectations were for revenue to come in at $8.33 billion, while its profits came in at $1.29 billion, or $1.01 a share, against $1.32 billion, or 99 cents a share, in the same quarter in 2024.

The firm, which has over 4,000 employees in Ireland, said that its revenues would rise 4.75 per cent to 5 per cent in the upcoming year.

14.15 - Investors growing bullish on EU equities

Investors are increasingly bullish on EU equities as nearly half expect higher growth in the region, according to a Bank of America survey of European fund managers.

Nearly half (45 per cent) anticipate strong European growth over the next 12 months, up from just 9 per cent in January and its highest level since May. A further 59 per cent believe inflation will drop over this timeframe.

The majority viewed German fiscal stimulus as the most likely driver for growth, followed by potential easing from the European Central Bank.

Vish Gain has more.

14.00 - Apartments in Google’s Bolands Mills offered out to key workers

A total of 46 apartments in Google’s Bolands Mill Quarter in Dublin have been offered out to key workers by the housing agency Clúid.

The apartments are being offered out at up to 36 per cent below market rate, to key workers such as nurses, gardaí and teachers.

These workers must demonstrate that they have ties to the local area, such as having been born or lived for over 5 years in a 1.5 km radius around the development.

Read more here.

13.45 - Xeinadin announces new head of assurance in Ireland

Sandra Clarke, managing partner for Ireland, Xeinadin; Seamus Hayes, head of assurance, Xeinadin and Derry Crowley, chief executive, Xeinadin. Picture: Michael O’Sullivan

Professional services group Xeinadin has announced Seamus Hayes as its new head of assurance and sustainability in Ireland.

The former EY partner will lead a team of more than 250 workers across the firm’s network of offices.

Xeinadi, which applies over 500 people in Ireland, announced in June last year that it planned to invest €40 million into Ireland over 18 months.

13.30 - Eight Irish-based firms targeted by activist investors in 2024

A total of eight Irish-based companies were targeted by activist investors in 2024, double the number seen in 2023, according to research from governance firm Diligent.

Ireland’s increase in activist investors comes against a notable decline in Europe: Germany dropped from 60 companies impacted in 2020 to just 13 in 2024, while French’s more than halved to 6 year on year.

The UK was the exception, with 46 companies targeted, the most in Europe and 10 more than 2023.

13.15 - Helen Dixon departs Comreg after a year in the role

Helen Dixon has announced her departure from the Commission for Communications Regulation (Comreg) after one year in the role.

Dixon, who was the State’s Data Protection Commissioner between 2014 and 2024, wrote on LinkedIn that after “18 years in regulatory leadership roles”, she’s coming at things from “different angles”.

“In departing ComReg, I want to thank the expert and committed staff there and wish them ongoing success; thank the wider stakeholders in postal and electronic communications services who represent a truly impressive, focussed but adaptable, sector,” she wrote.

Alice O’Leary has more.

13.00 - German investor outlook jumps by most in two years before election

Investor’s confidence in the German economy rose by its highest rate in two years, days before the country goes to vote for its new government.

The Zew index of expectations jumped to 26 from 10.3 in January.

Friedrich Merz, the leading candidate for the election, has promised to reduce taxes, regulation and government handouts in a more market friendly government.

Euronews has more.

12.45 - Midday market update

Roughly halfway through trading on Tuesday, and most markets were up in Europe on the back of peace talks in the Ukraine war.

Germany’s Dax had a marginal fall, but the Iseq All Share rose by 0.6 per cent and the FTSE 100 by 0.1 per cent.

Spain’s Ibex 35 saw a 0.5 per cent rise, while France’s CAC 40 was largely unchanged.

12.30 - China to use DeepSeek AI for its weather forecasts

China’s state weather agency is considering using DeepSeek, the local startup whose artificial intelligence model shook global markets last month, to power its forecasts and observations.

The China Meteorological Administration discussed “promoting the in-depth integration and application of DeepSeek” and “continuously improving the AI meteorological model” in a February 14 meeting attended by the agency’s chief engineer, Pan Jinjun.

DeepSeek has demonstrated a breakthrough lower-cost AI model that is seen as being competitive with those of OpenAI and Meta.

12.15 - Australian central bank cuts rates for first time since 2020

Australia's central bank cut rates for the first time in more than four years on Tuesday but warned it was too early to declare victory over inflation and was cautious about the prospects of further easing.

The rate cut will provide some relief to borrowers and comes as good news for Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, who is facing a tough election to be held no later than May 17. Speculation is growing that he may use the opportunity to call an early election.

Read more on Reuters.

12.00 - 20 pubs sold in Dublin in 2024 with value of €69.6 million

A total of 20 pubs were sold in Dublin with a total market value of about €69.6 million last year, an increase from 2023 when the same number of sales generated €47.3 million.

The new figures from estate agents Lisney show that a total of 21 licensed premises were publicly offered for sale in Dublin last year, a decrease on the 34 offered publicly in 2023.

Publicans remained the dominant purchaser class, accounting for 55 per cent of volume and 37 per cent of value, while developer activity also increased to 20 per cent of volume and 19 per cent of value, Lisney said.

Read more on on RTÉ.

11.45 - White House says Musk is not in control of DOGE

The White House has said in a court filing that Elon Musk is not an employee of the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) and has no decision making authority, despite being proclaimed as its leader by Donald Trump.

The agency, which has been tasked with rapidly cutting the federal budget, including thousands of layoffs of federal workers, said in a filing that Musk is a “non-career special government employee” similar to other senior advisers.

The Independent has more.

11.30 - Kerry Group’s local production helps shield group from US tariffs: Scanlon

Kerry Group chief Edmond Scanlon told Reuters that the group’s policy of local production shield it better from tariff risks than its competitors.

“Because of the local nature of our business, we're probably better positioned relative to many of our competitors... There might be a few challenges. There might be a few opportunities as well.”

“The overall philosophy seems to be, you know, Make America Healthy Again. And I feel we're very well positioned to help customers to make packaged food healthier.”

11.15 - Over 80 applicants for Norwegian wealth fund job

A total of 82 applications were made for the head of Norway’s €1.7 trillion sovereign fund, although its present chief is expected to stay in the role.

Current chief executive Nicolai Tangen’s first five year term comes to an end soon. However, he has reapplied for a second term and is widely expected to keep the job due to his homegrown popularity.

Of the 82 applicants, 80 were male, one female and one undisclosed. Applications came from a range of industries, including asset management, electricians and environmental campaigners.

Bloomberg has more, although the story was first reported by Norwegian business daily Dagens Naeringsliv.

11.00 - Version 1 appoints new chief commercial officer

Irish fintech Version 1 has appointed Roop Singh as its chief commercial officer as it eyes global expansion and the rollout of its “ambitious growth plans”.

Singh joins Version 1 from the IT services firm Birlasoft, where he served as chief executive for the Americas. Prior to that role, he was the company’s chief business officer and has also held positions such as head of financial services at IBM and senior consultant at Wipr.

Employing more than 3,600 people, Version 1 partners with organisations in the public and private sector to help them integrate technology that will support sustainable innovation.

Megan O’Brien has more.

10.45 - Lime posts 30% increase in booking as bike sharing app eyes IPO

Photo by David Paul Morris

Lime, the electric bike sharing app backed by Uber, saw its bookings increase by 30 per cent year on year, as well as posting its second year of positive free cash flow in 2024.

The San Franciso-based startup launched in more than 20 cities throughout the year, including Tokyo and Athens, growing its fleet of vehicles by 20 per cent to 270,000.

The firm is eyeing a public offering after first querying the idea in 2021.

Bloomberg has more.

10.30 - Kerry Group shares hit €100 after annual results

The share price of Kerry Group has surpassed €100 after the group released its 2024 annual results today.

This is fast approaching its 12 month high of €101 a share.

These were the last set of accounts to include its dairy business, which was sold for €500 million in 2024.

10.15 - Thames Water wins court backing for £3 billion debt package

Thames Water, the troubled UK water provider with 16 million customers and £19 billion in debt, has won court approval for a £3 billion debt package.

The deal will give the utility company £1.5bn in cash and £1.5 billion extra to give it time to try and push through price increases of 35 per cent, which have been appealed.

The firm had said it would run out of cash by late March if the emergency funding didn’t go ahead. It still needs to raise billions more to repair its finances.

The Guardian has more.

10.00 - Elon Musk’s xAI unveils Grok-3

Elon Musk’s artificial intelligence startup xAI showed off the updated Grok-3 model, showcasing a version of the chatbot technology that the billionaire has said is the “smartest AI on Earth.”

Across math, science and coding benchmarks, Grok-3 beats Alphabet’s Google Gemini, DeepSeek’s V3 model, Anthropic’s Claude and OpenAI’s GPT-4o, the company said via a live stream on Monday.

Grok-3 has “more than 10 times” the compute power of its predecessor and completed pre-training in early January, Musk said.

“We’re continually improving the models every day, and literally within 24 hours, you’ll see improvements,” he said.

More here.

09.45 - UK wage growth surges to 8 month high

UK wages grew by 5.9 per cent in the three months ending December, up from 5.6 per cent in the previous quarter, piling on pressure for the Bank of England to cut interest rates to curb inflation.

Data released by the Office for National Statistics also revealed that employment rose 107,000 to 33.86 million, while payrolled employees rose 20,600 to 30.4 million after being projected to fall by 30,000.

09.30 - Basil Bailey appointed new chief of Truelayer Ireland

TrueLayer, the fintech start-up that provides open banking services, has appointed Basil Bailey as its new chief executive officer for Ireland.

Bailey will also take over as general manager of the Stripe-backed firm’s European business.

TrueLayer, which was established in 2016, said that Bailey will oversee the commercial and regulatory functions of TrueLayer Ireland, which holds a European Payments Institution (PI) license and is regulated by the Central Bank of Ireland.

Vish Gain has more.

09.15 - Shared home charging and grants for taxi drivers in new EV plan

A pilot programme for shared home charging options, incentives for taxi drivers, and grants for electric motorcycles are all on the cards as the Department of Transport aims to accelerate the transition to electric vehicles (EVs).

The suite of initiatives, which will be funded by the department and Transport Infrastructure Ireland’s group on zero emissions vehicles, will be administered by the Sustainable Energy Authority of Ireland (SEAI).

Darragh O’Brien, the transport minister, said the grants will complement the existing supports for electric cars, commercial vans and charging infrastructure.

Megan O’Brien has more.

09.00 - Markets update - tetchy openings around Europe amid geopolitical uncertainty

Markets across Europe opened flat as ongoing talks over the war in Ukraine leave uncertainty in the air for investors. News of fresh talks did help European indices hit record high in trading on Monday, however.

The Iseq All Share was down by 0.2 per cent as of 08.55. The FTSE 100 was little changed, while Germany’s Dax saw a 0.17 per cent fall.

08.45 - Passenger cap at Dublin Airport risk to inbound growth, tourism officials warn minister

Photo by Fergal Phillips

The passenger cap at Dublin Airport could have a detrimental impact on the growth of inbound tourism in Ireland, officials at the Department of Enterprise have warned Peter Burke.

However, these ongoing constraints at the country’s main aviation hub provide regional airports with an opportunity to expand their services, the officials noted.

In a briefing note prepared for Burke, whose enterprise department now oversees tourism, officials told the minister that while the cap remained “a concern to the growth of inbound tourism”, airports such as Cork and Shannon could benefit by bringing “tourists directly into the regions”.

Cónal Thomas has more.

08.30 - Jobs in firms supported by state agencies hit record levels

Jobs in client companies of Enterprise Ireland, the IDA and Údarás na Gaeltachta have reached record levels, according to a new report from the enterprise department.

The department’s annual employment survey found that 546,763 jobs were supported by these agencies in 2024, an increase of 1.3 per cent on 2023’s figures. The IDA alone supported an extra 1,064 jobs year on year.

Peter Burke, the enterprise minister said the results “demonstrate the strength and resilience of our jobs market and industry in Ireland, in spite of the challenges posed by global economic and political headwinds”.

08.15 - Kerry Group posts revenues of €8 billion

Kerry Group reported group revenue of €8 billion for 2024, with revenue from continuing operations at €6.9 billion, with the food giant posting a 7.4 per cent increase in Ebitda to €1.25 billion.

Volume growth in its core Taste & Nutrition division grew at 3.4 per cent for the year, accelerating to 4.1 per cent in the fourth quarter. The segment also saw a 110-basis point improvement in Ebitda margin.

Adjusted earnings per share totalled 467.5 cent, which the company said, reflected a 9.7 per cent increase in constant currency.

Ellie Donnelly has more.

08.00 - Titanic Distillers secures £5 million in fresh funding

Belfast-based distillery Titanic Distillers has secured £5 million (€6.01 million) to expand its sales team, drive growth in new geographic markets and establish key distribution channels.

It received these funds from Whiterock Finance, an alternative lender based in the North.

The investment was part of Whiterock’s Growth Capital Fund, which makes investments of between £1 million and £5 million for minority shareholdings in growth and scaling companies in the North.

Emma Hanrahan has more.

07.45 - Children’s hospital builder seeking extra €853 million to complete construction

BAM, the builders of the new National Children’s Hospital, is demanding an extra €853 million to finish the long awaited construction, the Irish Independent reports.

This figure is €100 million above estimates delivered last Autumn at an Oireachtas committee hearing.

However, the National Paediatric Hospital Development Board (NPHDB) said that this extra cash outlay represents claims by BAM which have been independently valued at €48 million.

07.30 - Housing the key issue for new government as ‘planning paralysis’ hampers new builds

Housing has dominated the first weeks of the new government’s tenure, with politicians sparring on what measures to introduce to boost supply.

Cónal Thomas has a piece on the week ahead for cabinet as they mull tax breaks, water committees and compulsory purchase orders.

Killian Woods has analysis on Ireland’s “planning paralysis” and what steps can be taken to rectify flagging housebuilding.

07.15 - Asian markets update: Chinese stocks trim gains but Hong Kong continues push

Asian shares trimmed gains while the headline index from mainland China swung to an 0.8 per cent loss, with Hong Kong-listed tech stocks falling from a near three year high.

Stocks in China had raced ahead earlier in the day, after Xi Jinping met with Chinese business leaders which prompted hope for more private sector support. However, concerns over Ukraine peace talks saw a slide later in trading.

Japan’s Nikkei 225 rose 0.25 per cent. Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index jumped by 1 per cent on the dot. South Korea’s Kospi rose 0.6 per cent.

7.00 - Good morning

Good morning from the Business Post. Fionn Thompson here to keep you up to date on all the latest news as it happens.

Kick off your morning with Laura Roddy’s piece on data centre operators having to build or source their own energy sources.

Emma Hanrahan has a piece on how the “loud” LVMH labels are forging ahead as Saint Laurent and Gucci lag.

4.title: Amid The White Lotus 3 Release, BLACKPINK’s Lisa Spotted On Date With Rumoured Beau Frederic Arnault
4.snippet: Rumours have been swirling about BLACKPINK's Lisa dating Frederic Arnault, the son of LVMH founder Bernard Arnault.
4.content:
BLACKPINK's Lisa is often in the spotlight for both her music and personal life. Recently, rumours have been swirling about her dating Frederic Arnault, the son of LVMH founder Bernard Arnault. Although neither of them has confirmed the relationship, they’ve been seen together a few times, sparking excitement among fans.

BLACKPINK's Lisa spotted with rumoured boyfriend

Lisa is currently in Thailand to promote her acting debut in HBO’s ‘The White Lotus’ season 3. After completing her promotional tour in the U.S., the BLACKPINK star made a dazzling appearance at the premiere event in Thailand on February 14. Fans were taken by surprise when they spotted her rumoured boyfriend, Frederic Arnault, in the crowd.

Although Lisa and Frederic didn’t appear together at the event, fan pages later confirmed that the two spent time together in Thailand. On Sunday, February 16, a fan shared pictures on X (formerly Twitter), taken inside a restaurant. In the photos, Lisa wore a chic black outfit, while Frederic opted for a pink shirt. One photo captured a cozy moment between the rumoured couple, as they shared a meal with the cast and crew of ‘The White Lotus’, further fueling the dating rumours.

ALSO READ: Blackpink’s Lisa Shares Rare Moment With Her Mom At The White Lotus Season 3 Premiere, See Pics

lisa and frederic arnault eating with some of the white lotus cast. pic.twitter.com/2MeICKmwhm — 𝕗𝕠𝕣 𝕝𝕚𝕤𝕒 &. 𝕗𝕣𝕖𝕕 . (@fredericslisa) February 16, 2025

About The White Lotus

Meanwhile, ‘The White Lotus’ Season 3, created, written, and directed by Mike White, premiered on HBO on February 16 worldwide, and on JioHotstar in India on February 17. This season features an ensemble cast, including Leslie Bibb, Carrie Coon, Walton Goggins, Sarah Catherine Hook, Jason Isaacs, Michelle Monaghan, and Patrick Schwarzenegger, among others. The eight-episode comedy-drama anthology continues to captivate audiences with its intriguing storyline and star-studded performances.

5.title: Italian court lifts controls placed on Armani company over labour practices -February 18, 2025 at 10:02 am EST
5.snippet: An Italian court has ended early special administration imposed on a unit of the Armani fashion group over labour practices of its Chinese-owned...

6.title: China’s Love Affair With Luxury Has Cooled
6.snippet: SHANGHAI—Xie Weina used to buy luxury bags that cost $1,500 or more every couple of months. Last year, instead of bags, she spent about $2,800 on a gym...

7.title: French Stocks Snap 6-Session Winning Streak
7.snippet: The CAC 40 fell 0.3% to 8163 on Tuesday, ending a six-session winning streak as investors closely monitored geopolitical developments.
7.content:
The CAC 40 fell 0.3% to 8,163 on Tuesday, ending a six-session winning streak as investors closely monitored geopolitical developments.

Traders are keeping a close eye on the Russia-Ukraine peace talks, with U.S. and Russian officials set to meet in Saudi Arabia later today, without the participation of Ukraine or the EU. On the corporate front, shares of Capgemini fell nearly 8%, reaching a two-week low, after the company reported a 2% year-on-year decline in sales, although it surpassed expectations.

Edenred also saw a sharp drop, with shares falling 7.7% to a two-week low, even as the company reported a higher-than-expected annual core profit.

Moreover, luxury stocks struggled, with Kering, L’Oréal, Hermès, and LVMH seeing declines of 2.1%, 1.7%, 0.7%, and 0.2%, respectively.

In contrast, Thales stood out as the top performer, rising 1.5% to hit a new all-time high, followed by Stellantis NV, which gained 1.3%, and Société Générale, up 1.1%.

8.title: Decline In Watch Sales Takes Shine Off Encouraging Year Of Growth For Hermès
8.snippet: A decline in watch sales of 4.2% last year was the only blemish in an otherwise positive financial report from Hermès that shows the fashion house...

9.title: Sla the Label shutters following legal battle
9.snippet: Independent womenswear brand Sla the Label has announced it will be shutting down after a legal battle left it financially struggling.
9.content:
Independent womenswear brand Sla the Label has announced it will be shutting down after a legal battle left it financially struggling.

The news was announced on the Instagram account of founder Sarah Ashcroft, a fashion blogger who launched the brand back in 2019.

On her social media, Ashcroft said that after “six years of dedication, passion and relentless hard work, Sla has had to come to an end”.

The closure is the result of a legal battle with a manufacturer that Ashcroft said had breached the brand’s trust, leaving behind “catastrophic” impact and an “uphill struggle to recover from the financial damage” it caused.

“For over a year, I fought tirelessly to save the brand–exploring every possible avenue to keep it alive–but ultimately, the weight of this situation became impossible to overcome,” Ashcroft added.

It brings to an end yet another UK-based independent business, once again highlighting the currently challenging environment for such companies in the region.

Last year, celebrity-favoured womenswear brand The Vampire’s Wife closed its doors after facing hefty debt repayments, while reality star Kerry Katona’s own business, Kerry’s Boutique, also shuttered, with online filings stating that the retailer was dissolved via a compulsory strike-off.

Sla operated largely online over its lifespan, offering premium occasion and ready-to-wear collections to cater to a mission of “empowering women through fashion”.

0.title: Leonardo Ferragamo on maintaining brand values and independence
0.snippet: Florence-born Ferragamo remains in the hands of its founding family in an industry dominated by conglomerates like LVMH and Kering – its chairman shares why...
0.content:
Ferragamo chairman Leonardo Ferragamo has a busy few months ahead. A second-generation descendant of the family behind the Florence-based leather goods label, Leonardo started working at the company at the young age of 20 and has been instrumental in expanding Ferragamo’s presence globally, including in Hong Kong and China.

He is now tasked with the challenge of appointing a new CEO for the storied Italian house, one of the few independent luxury brands left in a landscape dominated by conglomerates such as LVMH and Kering.

Ferragamo’s spring/summer 2025 campaign starring Liu Wen. Photo: Handout

Advertisement

Earlier this year, Ferragamo, which is listed on the Italian Stock Exchange, reported that sales were down four per cent in the fourth quarter of 2024, with a 25 per cent drop in the Asia-Pacific region. Not long afterward, the company announced that it had parted ways with CEO Marco Gobetti, who’d joined in 2022.

Like most luxury brands, Ferragamo has not been immune to the headwinds of the Chinese economy. A drop in spending in mainland China has created uncertainty in a part of the world that had, until recently, experienced extreme growth.

On a recent visit to Hong Kong, during a whirlwind trip that also took him to Shanghai and Taipei, Leonardo sat down for a chat with Style.

What are the pros and cons of being an independent brand?

A look from the Ferragamo spring/summer 2025 collection. Photo: Handout

Many of the most prestigious brands in the world are independent, and I say that with great appreciation. Chanel , Armani, Zegna, Ralph Lauren, Prada – they’re all examples of success stories that have stayed independent. One of the advantages is that the family that controls the company can maintain a coherence behind the brand, and that’s very important. You can still be coherent when you’re part of a big group, but this element of consistency is a key [advantage] of independent brands. You can make choices outside the box and be more original as an independent brand , and you have more advantages long-term. In a case like Ferragamo, we have founding values and principles that make the difference.

There are also disadvantages. It’s a challenge to stay independent and stay competitive, especially when it comes to sourcing and the retail network, but we are very determined and do it.

1.title: How LVMH Helped Turn an Abandoned Miami Warehouse District Into a Luxury Hot Spot

2.title: LVMH-owned Napa Valley producer closes
2.snippet: Napa Valley's Newton Vineyard has announced that it will permanently close four years after it was ravaged by a wildfire.
2.content:
News

By Louis Thomas

Napa Valley’s Newton Vineyard has announced that it will permanently close four years after it was ravaged by a wildfire.

View this post on Instagram A post shared by Newton Vineyard (@newtonvineyard)

Founded by Englishman Peter Newton in 1977, Newton Vineyard grew to cover 260 hectares, around 48ha of which was under vine.

Luxury giant LVMH would acquire a majority stake in Newton Vineyard in 2001 – Newton would die in 2008, with his family retaining a small stake in the producer. The estate became particularly famous for its single vineyard wines, such as its Cabernet Sauvignon expressions.

Disaster struck in September 2020 with the outbreak of the Glass Fire which swept across Northern California. Newton Vineyard was one of a number of Napa producers to be affected by the inferno, losing a large area of vineyard and its winery building – some reports suggested that just 2ha of vines survived the fire. It did not produce a 2020 harvest, and the majority of the 2019 vintage, ageing in barrels, was also lost.

At the time, then-general manager Jean-Baptiste Rivail told local news outlet North Bay Business Journal: “We are working full steam ahead with our insurance partners and county officials to clean and plan the rebuilding and redevelopment — all our energy is focused on preparing our future and moving onward and upward. We are determined to rebuild!”

After this point, Newton Vineyard’s winemaking was undertaken in a temporary facility.

When db‘s American contributor Roger Morris examined the issue of wildfires in California last year, he noted that LVMH had not made any mention of rebuilding the Newton Vineyard winery.

It has now emerged that the producer will permanently cease to operate.

An email to members of Newton Vineyard’s wine club explained that the decision to close was “profoundly challenging”.

“We sincerely hope that everyone who has been touched by Newton Vineyard will continue to cherish the wines and memories we have created together,” it continued. “We are deeply grateful for the unwavering support we have received over the years from our valued consumers and dedicated fans.”

db has reached out to LVMH for comment on the closure.

Related news

Ontario liquor board denies tampering with Gretzky wine labels

Senators fight to support smoke-affected vintners

'Cabernet may be king but Merlot proved emperor'

3.title: Aoris Exited LVMH Moët Hennessy – Louis Vuitton, Société Européenne (LVMUY) as 2023 Earnings Proved to be Materially Above Normal

From driverless cars to medical breakthroughs, AI is on the cusp of a global explosion, and savvy investors stand to reap the rewards.

This isn’t a maybe – it’s an inevitability.

Early investors will be the ones positioned to ride the wave of this technological tsunami.

Ground Floor Opportunity: Remember the early days of the internet?

Those who saw the potential of tech giants back then are sitting pretty today.

AI is at a similar inflection point.

We’re not talking about established players – we’re talking about nimble startups with groundbreaking ideas and the potential to become the next Google or Amazon.

This is your chance to get in before the rockets take off!

Disruption is the New Name of the Game: Let’s face it, complacency breeds stagnation.

AI is the ultimate disruptor, and it’s shaking the foundations of traditional industries.

The companies that embrace AI will thrive, while the dinosaurs clinging to outdated methods will be left in the dust.

As an investor, you want to be on the side of the winners, and AI is the winning ticket.

The Talent Pool is Overflowing: The world’s brightest minds are flocking to AI.

From computer scientists to mathematicians, the next generation of innovators is pouring its energy into this field.

This influx of talent guarantees a constant stream of groundbreaking ideas and rapid advancements.

By investing in AI, you’re essentially backing the future.

The future is powered by artificial intelligence, and the time to invest is NOW.

Don’t be a spectator in this technological revolution.

Dive into the AI gold rush and watch your portfolio soar alongside the brightest minds of our generation.

This isn’t just about making money – it’s about being part of the future.

So, buckle up and get ready for the ride of your investment life!

5.title: LVMH, world leader in high-quality products
5.snippet: A family-run group, LVMH strives to ensure the long-term development of each of its Houses in keeping with their identity, their heritage and their...
5.content:
Tiffany & Co. and FIFA have unveiled the official FIFA Club World Cup™ Trophy, to be awarded to the winners of the premier edition of the new tournament, which will be staged in the United States from June 15 to July 13, 2025.

The new trophy will be lifted for the first time after the final at New York New Jersey MetLife Stadium.



Both prestigious and timeless, the trophy embodies the innovation, inclusive spirit and global reach of the new 32-team tournament. Boasting a 24-carat gold-plated finish, it features laser-engraved inscriptions that portray football’s rich history. They include a world map and the names of the 211 FIFA Member Associations, plus the six confederations.



The trophy’s central disc displays an array of icons that capture football’s traditions, with engravings in 13 languages and Braille.



Tiffany & Co. President and Chief Executive Officer Anthony Ledru stated: “With a legacy dating back 160 years, Tiffany & Co. has crafted some of the most iconic championship trophies in history, setting the standard for craft and design. The FIFA Club World Cup™ Trophy is the next chapter in our long history of creating the world’s most revered symbols of athletic achievement.”



This collaboration between Tiffany & Co. and FIFA showcases both the exceptional creative craftsmanship of Tiffany & Co., and FIFA’s commitment to celebrating both the past and the future of football around the world.

6.title: Meet The 3 Middle Eastern Designers Up For The LVMH Prize 2025
6.snippet: The 2025 LVMH Prize spotlights three Arab semi-finalists, marking the Middle East's growing influence in high fashion.
6.content:
Each year, the LVMH Prize for Young Fashion Designers not only provides emerging talent with financial support and mentorship but also introduces a new generation of names set to shape the industry’s future. The 2025 edition is no exception. For its 12th year running, the prize drew 2,300 applicants from around the world, all competing for a coveted spot.

Now, the competition has been whittled down to 20 semi-finalists from 15 countries. Stealing the spotlight? Three Arab designers, making waves and marking a significant moment for regional representation at fashion’s highest level. Their presence underscores the Middle East’s growing influence on the global stage—no longer a spectator in high fashion but a driving force.

On March 5 and March 6, these rising talents will present their collections in Paris, where both the public and an expert panel will cast their votes. The LVMH Prize 2025 will grant three awards: the Young Fashion Designers winner will receive a 400,000-euro endowment and a year of mentorship; the Karl Lagerfeld Prize runner-up will be awarded 200,000 euros and a year of mentorship; and the Savoir-Faire Prize recipient will receive a 200,000-euro grant along with mentorship.

Meet the Arab Finalists

Yasmin Mansour (Qatar)

Qatari designer Yasmin Mansour founded her eponymous brand in 2014, creating a conversation between sculptural elegance and artistic expression. Based in Qatar, her label is characterised by architectural silhouettes, intricate pleating, and a deep respect for traditional craftsmanship. Each piece is a tribute to artisanal excellence, reflecting her artistic vision, exceptional craftsmanship, and a commitment to sustainability.

With a thoughtful blend of texture and structure, Yasmin Mansour offers a refined take on luxury, merging fashion with contemporary art. Fresh off her win at the 2024 Fashion Trust Arabia Prize, Mansour continues to refine her signature aesthetic, which is both experimental and timeless. For her, fashion is more than just clothing—it’s about telling a story. Her designs exude a quiet sophistication, speaking to her unique ability to weave powerful narratives into each garment. Through her work, she aims to empower and celebrate femininity.

KML (Saudi Arabia)

Founded in 2022 by Ahmed and Razan Hassan, KML is a Saudi menswear brand that fuses research-driven design with a deep exploration of the evolution of human dress. KML’s collections strike a balance between historical references and contemporary relevance, with Ahmed Hassan’s razor-sharp tailoring defining the brand’s understated yet opulent aesthetic. This unique approach redefines Saudi menswear on the global stage.

KML’s design philosophy is rooted in the belief that fashion should reflect humanity’s ever-evolving identity. By looking into the history and transformation of clothing, KML creates meaningful, relevant designs that speak to our collective human story. Since its inception, Hassan’s research-based approach has led to collections that showcase precision and personality, establishing KML as a standout force in the region.

Renaissance Renaissance (Lebanon)

Cynthia Merhej, the creative force behind Renaissance Renaissance, infuses her rich sartorial heritage into an avant-garde brand that redefines femininity. Merhej seamlessly blends modern design elements with period-inspired details, creating collections that feature sharp, contemporary silhouettes softened by delicate touches. Her work challenges traditional notions of womanhood, engaging in a dialogue that connects historical influences with today’s fashion trends in a way that is both intellectually engaging and effortlessly wearable.

Renaissance Renaissance redefines occasion wear while honouring traditional craftsmanship. Entirely crafted in Beirut, the brand collaborates with local artisans and family-owned factories, ensuring a commitment to quality, sustainability, and social responsibility. By bridging eras, cultures, and identities, Merhej creates timeless garments that transcend fleeting trends. Her irreverent approach to femininity not only challenges established perceptions but also invites a deeper reflection on history, art, and the female body. A returning LVMH Prize contender since her shortlist appearance in 2021, Merhej’s work stands as a testament to innovative design and the evolving narrative of modern womanhood.

8.title: Four African Designers Named Among Semi-Finalists for LVMH Prize 2025
8.snippet: Tolu Coker, Torishéju Dumi, David Boyedoe and Yasmin Mansour are in the running for the biggest prize for young fashion designers.
8.content:
Four African designers are among the 20 semifinalists in the LVMH Prize 2025, the competition for emerging designers held annually since 2014. South African designer Thebe Magugu was the first African to win the prize in 2019. British Indian Nigerian designer Priya Ahluwalia was a finalist in 2020, and Cape Town-based Lukhanyo Mdingi won the Special Prize in 2021.

Coker, nominated for her eponymous brand, centers culture and identity in her designs, with inspiration for her collections ranging from a combination of the memories of her late activist father and the contemporary protest movement, End SARS, to her Yoruba culture and Pidgin English. ‘OLAPEJU,’ a collection from last year, is an ode to her mother, creating chic and colorful pieces directly inspired by the clothes her mum wore when she moved to London from Lagos in the 1970s.

Coker and Dumi have been lauded for championing sustainable practices, notably on the January 2024 cover of British Vogue alongside Priya Ahluwalia.

Dumi, nominated for her semi-eponymous brand Torishéju, also roots her work in her identity, blending influences and styles into captivating pieces. “Mami Wata,” a cross-seasonal collection released in early 2023, showed her strength at making, “esoteric, intelligent, and abstract design[s].” Dumi put together her first Paris Fashion Week show later that year with the collection, “Fire on the Mountain,” opened by the revered supermodel Naomi Campbell. The collection also led to Dover Street Market (DSM) carrying Torishéju in all its stores.

Boyedoe is the first Ghanaian to be named a semifinalist in the LVMH Prize. His semi-eponymous brand blends African heritage and ethical elegance into an “afro-luxurious” whole. Boyedoe is rooted in sustainability, with culture, folklore and eclectic patterns underscoring its pieces and collections. The brand’s pieces are made from discarded or unsold stock, upcycling them and finding inventive uses within the ethos of deconstruction and reconstruction.

Mansour, nominated for her eponymous brand , weaves texture and structure into her refined vision of luxury. Her brand’s pieces are committed to a unique, sculptural elegance by melding architectural silhouettes, intricate pleating, and a reverence for traditional craftsmanship. Mansour’s commitment to sustainability is underlined by the timeless nature of her designs, presenting creations that bridge fashion and contemporary art.

The LVMH semifinalists will present their collections in early March, after which over 80 experts will vote for the eight finalists. The LVMH Prize includes three awards: The LVMH Prize for Young Fashion Designers, the Karl Lagerfeld Prize, and the most recently added Savoir-Faire Prize. Winners of all three prizes will receive year-long mentorship programs and financial endowments ranging from €200,000 to €400,000 ($209,000 to $418,000).

0.title: LVMH’s Big Sports Bet
0.snippet: Louis Vuitton's high-flying parent company is making long-term deals in Formula One, professional soccer, and beyond.
0.content:
Formula One kicks off its Grand Prix season in Melbourne in March, and for the first time in more than a decade, Rolex’s gold-crown logo and brand name won’t adorn the podium, race track, and start clock. As part of a 10-year, multibrand deal between F1 and LVMH—the world’s largest luxury group—watchmaker TAG Heuer will take over official timekeeping honors, and Louis Vuitton will debut as the race title sponsor.

After a 25-year hiatus, Moët & Chandon—also an LVMH property—will return as F1’s dedicated champagne provider, replacing the competing bubbly brands that recent winners have sprayed into the crowds. The winemaker has also unseated Rolex’s naming rights to the Belgian Grand Prix in July.

LVMH’s brands—like their luxury peers—have long turned popular athletes into campaign ambassadors, lent their expertise to designing team uniforms, and courted wealthy fans through sponsorships. But the partnership—reportedly worth more than $100 million a year—is much more than a one-off publicity grab by a business more known for its fashion, jewelry, and beauty expertise. LVMH is becoming a serious sports power player.

Its portfolio brands were everywhere in last summer’s Olympics thanks to a €150 million investment: In the opening ceremony, Louis Vuitton monogrammed steamer trunks got prime placement, as performers like Céline Dion and Lady Gaga boated down the Seine in head-to-toe Dior. Team France competed in Berluti uniforms, and medals designed by jeweler Chaumet were presented on distinctive Vuitton-branded leather trays. (Its presence was so ubiquitous, some officials and fellow sponsors later complained to the media about the pervasiveness of the branding.)

In November, the Arnault family—headed by LVMH founder, chairman, and CEO Bernard Arnault—announced they had acquired a majority stake in Paris FC, a French second-tier soccer club. According to French media, the initial investment was valued at €100 to €200 million, and in the coming years, the Arnaults are expected to make a substantial push to both burnish the club’s brand and elevate its performance.

“I don’t think we’ve seen a luxury group take such broad strides across sport and sporting sponsorship,” Hugo Hensley, head of sports services at the valuation and strategy consultancy Brand Finance, tells Front Office Sports.

Jon Durr/Imagn Images

Brand awareness is a big part of this push, but the larger prize—and an opportunity afforded only by sports—is hooking the most valuable clients. Further, in wealth intelligence company Altrata’s latest billionaire census, it found that sports indexed as the top hobby for 70% of men and 29% of women, ranking above pursuits like arts and education.

Hensley sees the LVMH deals as a natural fit for the brand, reaching different audiences and allowing the company to flex a variety of skills, from overhauling a merchandise collection to hosting events with top-spending clients.

“There is a real camaraderie in sport that is very hard for luxury to find anywhere else,” says Matteo Atti, a professor of luxury business at the International University of Monaco. “It tends to be so polished that you hardly ever go beyond the ads, and sport removes that layer of veneer and can bring people again face-to-face.”

LVMH is hardly the only luxury fashion player staking its claim on sports: In 2023, François-Henri Pinault, who leads the conglomerate’s biggest rival, Kering, acquired a majority stake in Creative Artists Agency, the entertainment and sports agency that reps many of the world’s top athletes. He has also owned the French soccer team Stade Rennais FC since 1998. Chanel, meanwhile, signed a long-term deal last year to become title sponsor and timekeeping partner of The Boat Race, the much-watched rowing competition between Oxford and Cambridge universities.

But with LVMH’s deep pockets and 75-brand portfolio, it’s able to go much bigger.

LVMH is pushing hard off the back of its successful premium sponsorship of the 2024 Paris Olympics.

In October 2024, LVMH inked the F1 deal. The brand should see immediate impacts at the racetrack, among cars going 200 miles per hour. F1 is an obvious target for the luxury group, with its audience of global travelers and business leaders, including many ultra-wealthy fans who will jet to Miami or Monaco for a weekend to take in a race.

“I think Formula One retains that simplicity and immediacy that is incredible. But also, I think for luxury, specifically, it has now become so technical; it really showcases a level of know-how that is unbeatable,” says Atti, who is also global chief marketing officer at private aviation company Vista, which, like LVMH, has made significant investments in motorsports, similarly attracted both by its international appeal and the opportunities to get up close and personal with clients. “It’s the physical strength, the physical prowess, preparation, and alignment with the machinery—all of that together, against the weather, against the conditions, and against all the odds.”

Andy Abeyta/Imagn Images

Shortly after, in November 2024, the Arnault family announced its investment in Paris FC, aiming to take a lower-division club with revenue struggles and turn it into a compelling brand despite a difficult market. (Red Bull was part of the investment as well as a minority stakeholder.)

Reaching the status of Paris’s more famous soccer club will be a significant challenge, even for a family with near-limitless resources and decades of branding expertise. Paris Saint-Germain, or PSG, is not only ranked first in France’s top league but has also achieved a global fashion prestige in and of itself, with boutiques in London, New York City, and Seoul, and its ongoing collaboration with Nike’s Jordan Brand. Paris FC has no such merchandising program or international brand recognition yet, but Hensley says the potential is huge. London, after all, has seven teams competing in the Premier League. Why shouldn’t Paris have two top contenders?

While PSG is majority-owned by a subsidiary of the Qatari sovereign wealth fund, Paris FC will stand out as one of the few locally owned competitors in French soccer. Its success, then, has the potential to be a matter of national pride, and LVMH has a vested interest in cultivating France’s reputation for excellence and savoir-faire. People love to cheer for the underdog, and luxury executives understand the value of an origin story, says Atti. If Paris FC, currently in second in Ligue 2, were to reach the top flight for the first time since 1978–1979, it would be among the most compelling modern ownership success stories.

There are hurdles, including on-the-field performance. But LVMH and the Arnaults can succeed, he tells FOS, comparing it to the trajectory of a Louis Vuitton staple that went from ordinary to extraordinary: “You can go from the Louis Vuitton trunk that was done by a guy called Louis, and that was nothing but a trunk, to what it then became.”

These three massive investments happened within six months, and LVMH has the resources to continue to expand if it wants. The group took in nearly €85 billion in revenue last year, and the opportunities are nearly endless; the money they’ve put into these sports trumps any other company—yet for LVMH’s bottom line, the money they are infusing is just a drop in the bucket.

Milton Pedraza, founder and CEO of the Luxury Institute, tells FOS he expects more investment to come, even if they don’t move as fast as they have within the past year.

“They like to start small, incubate, and then scale and elevate,” Pedraza says. Eventually, he says he could see the group having a sports portfolio like the Middle Eastern sovereign funds that have invested heavily in sports clubs around the world. “There are all kinds of opportunities for them, but they’re meticulous, so they test and learn.”

He continues, “Their job is to shatter myths and stereotypes and break through to new innovations. I don’t think there’s any sport that has a limit on it. If someday they want to do cornhole, so be it.”

1.content:
Belmond invites you to immerse yourself in an ocean of calm and tranquility with the launch of its new film series entitled “Long Shots”.

Embracing the ‘slow TV’ phenomenon, these 60-minute films are designed for passive viewing and active dreaming, capturing the sights and sounds of iconic Belmond locations around the world in exquisite detail. Anchored to Belmond’s ‘Slow Luxury’ brand DNA and steeped in the value of time and mindful living, the “Long Shots” series offers a sampling of Belmond’s incomparable experiences around the world.



In a world where social media video clips are becoming shorter – and attention spans dwindling – the ‘slow TV’ phenomenon has emerged as an intriguing counterbalance.



“Long Shots” offers viewers a captivating immersive experience, transporting them to Belmond’s enchanting locations, starting with Portofino, Rio de Janeiro, Scotland, Sardinia, Amalfi and Burgundy. A total immersion in the serene beauty of each destination, the “Long Shots” films invite viewers on a unique sensorial journey.

3.title: The LVMH Prize 2025 Reveals 3 Arab Finalists
3.snippet: Since its inception in 2013, the LVMH Prize has been fashion's most closely watched crystal ball, forecasting the industry's next emerging talents.
3.content:
On the other hand, Yasmin Mansour, the Qatari designer whose namesake brand recently earned her the 2024 Fashion Trust Arabia Prize, channels a refined sculptural elegance that feels timeless and experimental. Her work, with its fusion of art and fashion, embodies a quiet sophistication that speaks to her unique ability to weave powerful narratives into each garment. “My designs aim to empower and celebrate femininity,” she says, “fashion is not just about clothes, it’s about telling a story.”

KML, the Saudi menswear brand helmed by Ahmed Hassan rounds up the regional mix. Since its founding in 2022, Hassan’s research-based design philosophy has been a deep dive into the relationships between clothing and identity, resulting in collections that exude precision and personality. His razor-sharp tailoring is a study in minimalism and restraint, yet it's paired with a striking grandeur that channels a distinctly oriental, glamour-imbued sensibility.

These three designers from the region join an eclectic and promising group of creatives from Ghana, Japan, South Korea, Denmark, the United States, and beyond. The full list of semi-finalists includes Alainpaul by Alain Paul (France), All-in by Benjamin Barron (United States) and Bror August Vestbø (Norway), Boyedoe by David Boye-Doe Kusi (Ghana), Francesco Murano (Italy), Josh Tafoya (United States), Meruert Tolegen by Meruert Planul-Tolegen (United States), MFPEN by Sigurd Bank (Denmark), Nicklas Skovgaard (Denmark), Penultimate by Xiang Gao (China), Pillings by Ryota Murakami (Japan), Sinéad O’Dwyer (Ireland), Steve O Smith (United Kingdom), Tolu Coker (United Kingdom), Torisheju by Torishéju Dumi (United Kingdom), Young N Sang by Sang Lim Lee and Youngshin Hong (South Korea), and Zomer by Danial Aitouganov (The Netherlands) and Soshiotsuki by Soshi Otsuki (Japan). It’s a snapshot of where fashion is now—and where it’s headed.

The LVMH Prize 2025 offers three awards: the Young Fashion Designers winner receives a 400,000-euro endowment and a year of mentorship; the runner-up for the Karl Lagerfeld Prize gets 200,000 euros and a year of mentorship; and the Savoir-Faire Prize includes a 200,000-euro grant and one-year mentorship.

The winners, as always, will be revealed in a grand ceremony later this year, an event that in recent history has catapulted past recipients—think Grace Wales Bonner, Nensi Dojaka, and S.S. Daley—into fashion’s stratosphere.

For now, though, all eyes are on March 5th and 6th when they will present their most recent collections during Paris Fashion week. Twenty designers, one room, and a collective vision of fashion’s next chapter—it’s a thrilling prospect.

7.title: Billionaire Bernard Arnault’s heir spotted with Blackpink Lisa’s family in Bangkok
7.snippet: Frédéric Arnault, the son of French billionaire Bernard Arnault, was seen with the family of Lisa, a member of the K-pop group Blackpink, at the Bangkok...
7.content:
Frédéric Arnault, the son of French billionaire Bernard Arnault, was seen with the family of Lisa, a member of the K-pop group Blackpink, at the Bangkok premiere of the third season of “The White Lotus.”

Lisa, a member of the K-pop girl group Blackpink, at the premiere of the third season of the drama series "The White Lotus" Feb. 14, 2025. Photo from Lisa's Instagram

Pinkvilla reported that at the Feb. 14 event, Arnault kept a low profile but was still recognized by attendees. Videos showing the billionaire heir with the singer’s family and entourage circulated widely on social media.

This was not the first sighting of Arnault in Thailand with the Blackpink star. Last month, social media buzzed with footage purportedly showing the pair at Bangkok’s Wat Arun Temple.

The public became aware of their connection after Arnault began following Lisa on Instagram in 2022.

Lisa, born Pranpriya Manoban and currently 28 years old, launched her career with Blackpink in 2016 and embarked on a solo venture in 2021 with her album "Lalisa." Her single "Money" propelled her to become the first K-pop artist to achieve over 1 billion streams on Spotify with a single song.

Known as a fashion icon, she represents high-profile brands such as Celine and Bulgari, and boasts over 105 million followers on Instagram.

Arnault, 30, serves as CEO of the watch division at LVMH, managing prestigious labels including Hublot, TAG Heuer, and Zenith.

As of Feb. 17, Forbes lists Bernard Arnault and his family as the fifth wealthiest in the world, with a net worth of US$192.9 billion, primarily from their LVMH stakes in luxury brands like Christian Dior, Fendi, Loewe, Celine, and Bulgari.

"The White Lotus," created for HBO, is an American black comedy drama anthology television series. Lisa’s role in the third season as Mook, a hotel receptionist, marks her acting debut in Hollywood.

9.title: TAG Heuer is the first title sponsor of F1’s Monaco Grand Prix
9.snippet: TAG Heuer is celebrating a new milestone. The Swiss luxury watchmaker, owned by LVMH, has etched its name into history as the first title partner of the...
9.content:
The LVMH-owned Swiss watchmaker was recently appointed as Formula 1’s official timekeeper

TAG Heuer is celebrating a new milestone.

The Swiss luxury watchmaker, owned by LVMH, has etched its name into history as the first title partner of the Formula 1 Grand Prix de Monaco. This partnership follows the company’s role as the official timekeeper for Formula 1, marking a new chapter for both the 100-year-old motorsport event and the watch brand.

Celebrating its 75th year in Formula 1, TAG Heuer’s continued association with the event highlights its deep-rooted connection to motorsport and the celebrated Monaco race. The brand’s rich history with the Circuit de Monaco is intertwined with its iconic TAG Heuer Monaco watch collection, which has become synonymous with the event. As a result, the race will now officially be known as the Formula 1 TAG Heuer Grand Prix de Monaco.

The luxury watchmaker will be fully integrated into the action throughout the weekend with trackside placements. To mark this historic partnership, a new logo has been designed, which will appear across various platforms where TAG Heuer is showcased. Additionally, the iconic TAG Heuer Monaco clocks will be prominently displayed throughout the paddock, making their debut as a new fixture.

TAG Heuer’s legacy in Monaco spans decades, with renowned drivers like Jochen Rindt, Niki Lauda, Alain Prost, and Ayrton Senna all sporting Heuer chronographs during their victories at the legendary race. In recent years, the brand’s presence has continued, supporting modern-day champions such as Daniel Ricciardo, Max Verstappen, and Sergio Pérez as they celebrated podium finishes on the Côte d’Azur. This multi-year deal also expands TAG Heuer’s involvement with motorsport, as the brand becomes a key partner of the Rallye Monte-Carlo Historique.

“Monaco is truly our spiritual home, encapsulating much of what we stand for at TAG Heuer,” says its CEO, Antoine Pin, in a press statement. “The spirit of competition, the challenging street course that rewards those who show the greatest mental resilience and physical strength, a place where driver’s push themselves to achieve their absolute best, we are honoured and delighted to renew our partnership with the Automobile Club de Monaco and extend our activities in the Principality with TAG Heuer being the first to hold this prestigious title.”

And you can check out all those new track additions for yourself during the F1 race, which takes place from 22 to 25 May 2025 this spring.

This story was first published on Robb Report USA. Featured photo by Xavier Bonilla/NurPhoto via Getty Images

0.title: LVMH’s New Push: World’s Most Powerful Luxury Group Is Coming for Sports
0.snippet: Louis Vuitton's high-flying parent company is making long-term deals in Formula One, professional soccer, and beyond.
0.content:
